subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] on vs. ah
msgSnippet: Since it s a Phonic script, why any rules. If you like to say something with a Ah sound, say it, if you like Awe sounds use it. What I ve found to be a benefit
messageBody:
Since it's a Phonic script, why any rules. If you like
to say something with a Ah sound, say it, if you like
Awe sounds use it.

What I've found to be a benefit of QS is that I can
hear the writer acent within the writing and I like
that.

Chuck

--- kyudosha <kyudosha@...> wrote:
> My main problem, however, is that there seems to be
> no
> easily-definable rule as to which character to use
> under which
> circumstances. Shouldn't there be a convention as
> to which is used or
> not used if no differences are perceived? Should it
> be 32 or 34 for
> QS?
>
> Perhaps if a British person could explain to me, in
> fairly
> straightforward terms, how they know which sound
> goes where when they
> see it written, it will click for me. Or is it
> simply a matter of
> memorization?
>
> Are there any American English speakers who hear
> these differences and
> can illuminate me?
>


__________________________________

Since it's a Phonic script, why any rules. If you like
to say something with a Ah sound, say it, if you like
Awe sounds use it.

What I've found to be a benefit of QS is that I can
hear the writer acent within the writing and I like
that.

Chuck
